awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Lift in the Vertical Shear of Southerly Winds: A Mechanism of Elevated Convection at Night in the United States Great Plains
awd_abstract_narration:
One of the unique features of warm season weather in the U.S. Great Plains is that heavy precipitation takes place most frequently between midnight and early morning. Such nocturnal heavy precipitation contributes to nearly 80% of daily convective precipitation, critically affecting water resources availability, the economy, and the safety of the communities in the region. This nocturnal heavy precipitation is counterintuitive in the sense that the intensive convective activity over the Great Plains occurs at late night when the lower-troposphere is stably stratified, and the convective available potential energy is low. This paradoxical situation challenges the traditional understanding of development of severe convection yet also presents an opportunity for exploring new mechanisms for severe nocturnal convection and rainfall in the U.S. Great Plains. 

The goal of this study is to examine a mechanism that initiates nocturnal convection in the absence of passage of fronts or convective complex with a low level of convective available potential energy in the lower troposphere. The significance of outcomes of this study is the exploring of a new mechanism for warm season severe convection and rainfall in the Great Plains at mid-night to early morning hours. The validation of the new mechanism will fill the gap in the knowledge of initiation of nocturnal convection in the absence of frontal boundaries and convective complex and will extend the knowledge of nocturnal convection beyond the traditional thinking. The findings will help improve model capabilities to predict the timing and intensity of severe convection and rainfall in the U.S. Great Plains. The broader impacts of this study also include its potential to improve the safety and wellbeing of the communities across the U.S. Great Plains and, through education, expanding local public schools' science education programs by engaging students in learning fluid dynamics and appreciating the impacts of geosciences in improving people's lives.

The central hypothesis is that the nocturnal intensification of the low-level southerly wind in the Great Plains is subject to Coriolis deflection, which would in turn lead to the development of a vortex rotating along the horizontal axis pointing to the north (the northern vortex). Interactions of the northern vortex with the wind blows from the Rockies generate a lift that can elevate air in the lower-troposphere high enough to initiate convection, responsible for heavy precipitation in the hours between mid-night and early morning in the Great Plains. The main research tasks are 1) identifying processes leading to development of the northern vortex; 2) quantifying the condition that creates the lift of the vortex; 3) quantifying the roles of the atmospheric moisture in generating the lift; and 4) identifying the missing or incorrectly described processes that have failed current models in reproducing the elevated convection of this kind.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF NEBRASKA

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
To accomplish the Objective 4 of this project in year 4, we tested the hypothesized lift mechanism in a condition more realistic and relevant to the US Great Plains. As planned, we used the WRF model in this study. The first step is to examine/verify if a horizontal vortex, similar to the northern vortex used in our cloud models, can be generated by the vertical shear of the southerly winds in the Great Plains low-level jet (GPLLJ). Because of the Coriolis torque, the southerly winds will be veering eastward while travelling northward from the Gulf of Mexico. By the time it reaches the central Great Plains the flow should have a strong westerly component. Moreover, there should be vertical shear of these westerly winds because of the vertical shear of the southerly wind in GPLLJ and corresponding varying Coriolis torque on them. If the vertical shear of the westerly wind is strong enough a horizontal vortex pointing to the north (the northern vortex) can form. Interactions of this northern vortex with the mean zonal wind could result in a lift along the east edge of the northern vortex. This lift can accelerate vertical motion and initiate convection and storm. (This lift offers another potential mechanism for contributions of horizontal vortex to the spin up of severe rotation in the vertical direction because the vertical motion initiated by the lift can generate strong rotation through horizontal convergence.)  

We used the WRF model with various lateral boundary conditions to examine if the northern vortex can form. The WRF model has four available types of lateral boundary conditions: open boundary condition, periodic boundary condition, symmetric boundary condition, and realistic/specified boundary conditions.

We used the realistic boundary conditions and tested the WRF model by using it to simulate an observed convective storm case in the Great Plains during the PECAN field campaign. The model simulation was consistent with the observed (described in year 3 progress report). This validation assured that the WRF was correctly set and working properly. The validated WRF model was used to examine the northern vortex formation in the Great Plains.

The focal process of the northern vortex formation is the Coriolis torque on the southerly winds in the GPLLJ. We need to have proper lateral boundary conditions to test Coriolis? effect/strength on veering the southerly flow and creating the westerly perturbation winds. The ideal boundary conditions for this test would be fixed southerly winds in the southern boundary of the model and open boundary condition along other three boundaries. Among the options of model boundary condition, we used open, periodic, and specified boundary conditions. An example of the results is shown below for a specified boundary condition with a fixed southerly jet at the southern boundary and open boundary conditions at the other three boundaries. The initial wind field inside the model domain is shown in Fig. 1. There is no zonal wind (u=0) at the initial time along the boundaries and also inside the model domain. Model simulated wind fields at the 6th and 12th hour are shown in Figs. 2 and 3, respectively. There is clearly eastward veering of the southerly wind at model grids near the southern boundary where the southerly wind is the strongest. The westerly wind component strengthens as the time increases as shown by the stronger westerly winds in the southern tier of the domain at hour 12 than hour 6. This Coriolis effect diminishes northward into the domain as the meridional wind changes to be northerly (Fig. 1).

These 850hPa results from this example confirm that strong southerly jet entering the Great Plains in late spring and early summer months can cause strong westerly wind anomalies. Different intensity of the southerly wind at different elevations (the GPLLJ has a jet core around 875hPa) can result in different magnitude of westerly wind at different elevations from this same process. This dependence of the eastward veering on the strength of the southerly winds indicates that differences in westerly wind component resulting from this process alone can cause the vertical shear of westerly winds. At proper conditions this vertical shear can give the birth of a northern vortex. This vortex can interact with zonal wind and raise the potential for a lift as described in our cloud model results.

We use all resources and time to further these numerical experiments to identify such conditions for the development of northern vortex strong enough to be comparable to that used in our cloud models. That work was incomplete however (though still continuing) because of lack of funding and time when the project comes to its end.

Fig. 1: Initial wind inside the model domain.

 

Fig. 2: Winds inside the model domain at 6 hour of integration.

 

Fig. 3: Winds inside the model domain at 12 hour of integration.


Last Modified: 06/13/2023
Modified by: Qi S Hu
por.por_txt_cntn:

As planned, we used the WRF model in this study. (This lift offers another potential mechanism for contributions of horizontal vortex to the spin up of severe rotation in the vertical direction because the vertical motion initiated by the lift can generate strong rotation through horizontal convergence.)

The focal process of the northern vortex formation is the Coriolis torque on the southerly winds in the GPLLJ. We need to have proper lateral boundary conditions to test Coriolis? effect/strength on veering the southerly flow and creating the westerly perturbation winds. The ideal boundary conditions for this test would be fixed southerly winds in the southern boundary of the model and open boundary condition along other three boundaries. Among the options of model boundary condition, we used open, periodic, and specified boundary conditions. An example of the results is shown below for a specified boundary condition with a fixed southerly jet at the southern boundary and open boundary conditions at the other three boundaries. This dependence of the eastward veering on the strength of the southerly winds indicates that differences in westerly wind component resulting from this process alone can cause the vertical shear of westerly winds. At proper conditions this vertical shear can give the birth of a northern vortex. This vortex can interact with zonal wind and raise the potential for a lift as described in our cloud model results.

We use all resources and time to further these numerical experiments to identify such conditions for the development of northern vortex strong enough to be comparable to that used in our cloud models. That work was incomplete however (though still continuing) because of lack of funding and time when the project comes to its end.
